Award.AwardTitle: Electrified jets in the presence of a co-flowing liquid - A route to fine emulsions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The precision manipulation of streams of fluids with microfluidic devices is revolutionizing many fluid-based technologies. In particular, microfluidics offers unprecedented possibilities for controlled mixing of components to generate drops as templates for novel materials. However, despite the promise of these small-scale devices, the droplets and particle sizes that can be produced are rarely smaller than ~10 micrometers in diameter; this excludes materials in the colloidal domain of great fundamental and technological value.
The objective of this project is to effectively couple hydrodynamic and electric forces to generate, in steady-state, drops with sizes that can be tuned from well below to well above the micron scale. The intellectual merit resides in understanding and experimentally controlling the mechanism by which drops are generated in capillary-based microfluidic devices in the presence of electric fields. In particular, this research will elucidate how electric fields affect drop formation in co-flowing liquid streams, where one liquid is injected through a capillary tube into another immiscible liquid, and focus on the fundamental fluid mechanics controlling the process. The project involves the study of jet formation under the action of electric fields and the study of the hydrodynamic stability of these jets against the growth of both varicose, axisymmetric perturbations and off-axis, lateral instabilities.
The broader impact of the project is provided by the use of this fundamental knowledge to generate monodisperse emulsions with an unprecedented tunability of the drop size; this is industrially relevant, as drops are used in many everyday products, including food, cosmetic, heath and personal care products. Through the involvement of industrial partners we will additionally enhance the education of undergraduate students, who will not only learn how to use technologically relevant instrumentation and acquire a deep fundamental understanding of the relevant fluid mechanics involved in drop formation processes, but who will also broaden their training with these interactions. Additionally, the visual appeal of the research we plan to conduct will aid the preparation of new courses and lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The steady-state generation of droplets inside microfluidic devices in the presence of electric fields is challenging due to the inherent instability of the resultant charged drops; these will tend to discharge anywhere with a lower electric potential disrupting the original electric field and thus the drop generation process. We have successfully overcome this difficulty by using the injected liquids themselves as wires and electrodes in glass-based microfluidic devices. We have employed this electro-coflow technique to study fundamental questions related to electrospray and whipping instabilities. The former is the workhorse of spray atomization of small droplets, while the latter plays an essential role in the electrospinning of polymer solutions for fiber generation. In particular, we have elucidated the behavior of the electrified jets generated in electro-coflow. Interestingly, we find that these jets often bend off axis and develop a steady-state whipping structure corresponding to a conical helix. This is in contrast to what was typically seen before, where whipping behaved chaotically, and emphasizes the importance of the outer coflowing liquid in our experiments. In addition, we find have identified a new emission mode consisting in a planar whipping structure that oscillates at a frequency that depends on the applied electric field. Finally, we have also used electro-coflow to generate emulsions with average size above, comparable and below the diameter of the injection needle.

The project has also resulted in a strong partnership with Procter and Gamble. During the project, they have hosted an undergraduate student on two occasions, undoubtedly contributing to his education and experience. We are currently collaborating with them on drop formation problems. There have also been a large number of participants in the project, including post-docs, graduate and undergraduate students, whom have all been mentored and trained in the laboratory, in critical thinking, and in the theoretical aspects required to perform the electrically assisted microfluidic experiments. Additionally, a new Soft Matter course has been developed and taught, with enrollment from students interested in the Sciences as well as in Engineering.

Overall, this project has advanced our current understanding of electrically assisted drop formation and electrified jet behavior, and contributed to the training and education of some of the future scientists and engineers of our society.
